definitions: designed to draw attention away from something else by creating a distraction or misleading focus
examples: The military used diversionary tactics to confuse the enemy
His diversionary remarks shifted attention from the main issue

definitions: turned aside or redirected from an original path, purpose, or intended destination
examples: The diverted traffic caused major delays downtown
Her diverted attention made her miss the announcement

definitions: providing amusement or entertainment that pleasantly occupies one's attention and time
examples: The children found the puppet show quite diverting
She told diverting stories about her travels abroad

definitions: separated or split into different parts, sections, or groups
showing disagreement or conflicting opinions within a group
examples: The divided highway had a median between lanes
The property was divided equally among the heirs
The committee was divided on the proposed changes
Public opinion remains divided about the new policy

definitions: able to be divided or separated, especially in mathematics without leaving a remainder
examples: The number twelve is divisible by three and four
The inheritance was divisible among all family members

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a division within an organization, structure, or classification system
examples: The divisional manager oversees three departments
They competed in the divisional championship last weekend

definitions: tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people by creating opposing groups or factions
examples: The politician's divisive rhetoric split the community
They avoided divisive topics at the family dinner

definitions: having legally ended a marriage through formal dissolution
completely separated or removed from something
examples: The divorced couple shared custody of their children
She had been divorced for three years
His theories seemed divorced from practical reality
The decision was divorced from any emotional consideration

definitions: having a sensation of spinning and losing balance, often with nausea
silly, scatterbrained, or lacking in seriousness
examples: The dizzy patient needed to sit down immediately
Looking down from the tower made her feel dizzy
Her dizzy behavior at parties annoyed her friends
He made another dizzy mistake in his calculations

definitions: ready to accept control or instruction without resistance; submissive and easily managed
examples: The docile horse was perfect for beginner riders
The usually docile students became restless before vacation

definitions: relating to or involved in the highest academic degree awarded by universities
examples: She defended her doctoral thesis on climate change
The doctoral program requires four years of study

definitions: relating to or concerned with religious, political, or philosophical doctrines and their teaching
examples: The church faced doctrinal disputes over modern interpretations
Their doctrinal differences led to a organizational split

definitions: recorded in written, photographic, or other permanent form as evidence or information
examples: The documented evidence supported her insurance claim
All procedures must be properly documented for compliance

definitions: dishonest, unreliable, or of questionable quality or legality
potentially dangerous, risky, or likely to fail
examples: That dodgy salesman tried to overcharge us
The website looked dodgy so I didn't enter my details
The dodgy bridge swayed dangerously in the wind
My dodgy knee acts up whenever it rains

definitions: showing determination and refusing to give up despite difficulties or opposition
examples: Her dogged pursuit of justice inspired many people
The detective's dogged investigation finally solved the case

definitions: inclined to lay down principles as undeniably true without considering evidence or others' opinions
examples: His dogmatic approach alienated potential supporters
The professor was less dogmatic than her reputation suggested

definitions: having a rounded vault forming the roof of a building or structure
examples: The domed cathedral dominated the city skyline
They built a domed greenhouse for tropical plants

definitions: tamed and kept as a pet or on a farm, adapted to living with humans
examples: Domesticated animals depend on humans for survival
The domesticated cat still showed some wild instincts

definitions: controlled, ruled over, or having the most important or conspicuous position
examples: The dominated territories sought independence from colonial rule
The mountain dominated the landscape for miles around

definitions: exercising power and influence over others in an overbearing or intimidating way
examples: Her dominating personality made teamwork difficult
The dominating team won by a huge margin

definitions: asserting one's will over others in an arrogant, overbearing, or tyrannical way
examples: His domineering attitude drove away potential friends
The domineering manager never listened to employees' suggestions

definitions: having been completed, finished, or brought to an end
cooked thoroughly or to the desired degree
examples: The done deal cannot be changed now
When you're done reading, please return the book
The steak is done just the way you like it
Check if the cake is done by inserting a toothpick

definitions: certain to fail, die, or experience destruction or terrible misfortune
examples: The doomed expedition never reached its destination
Their doomed relationship ended exactly as predicted

definitions: under the influence of drugs, especially performance-enhancing or recreational drugs
treated or impregnated with a foreign substance to modify properties
examples: The doped athlete was banned from competition
The doped patient remained unconscious during surgery
The doped silicon semiconductor had enhanced conductivity
They used doped glass for the special optical lens

definitions: temporarily inactive, asleep, or showing no signs of activity but capable of becoming active
examples: The dormant volcano hadn't erupted for centuries
Many plants remain dormant during the winter months

definitions: relating to or situated on the back or upper surface of an organism
examples: The shark's dorsal fin cut through the water
The dorsal view shows the butterfly's wing patterns

definitions: marked or covered with dots or small round marks at intervals
examples: She wore a dotted dress to the party
The dotted line shows where to cut the paper

definitions: slightly mad or eccentric, especially in an amusing or harmless way
examples: Her dotty aunt collected hundreds of ceramic frogs
The dotty professor often forgot which class he was teaching

definitions: increased to twice the original size, amount, number, or extent
examples: The doubled recipe feeds twelve people instead of six
Sales doubled after the new marketing campaign

definitions: feeling uncertain about something or unlikely to happen or be successful
examples: She remained doubtful about his explanation
It's doubtful whether we'll finish on time

definitions: feeling or expressing uncertainty, skepticism, or lack of conviction about something
examples: The doubting investor withdrew from the project
Her doubting expression showed she didn't believe him

definitions: relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance
examples: The dour receptionist rarely smiled at visitors
His dour expression never changed during the meeting

definitions: unfashionable and dull in appearance, typically used of a woman's clothes
examples: She replaced her dowdy wardrobe with modern styles
The dowdy hotel needed a complete renovation

definitions: in or toward the part of a sports field defended by the opposing team
examples: The quarterback threw a long pass downfield
The downfield blocking cleared a path for the runner

definitions: moving or leading toward the bottom of a hill or slope
becoming progressively easier or requiring less effort
examples: The downhill portion of the race was the fastest
We parked at the downhill end of the street
After the merger, everything went downhill for the company
Once we finish this part, it's all downhill from here

definitions: thoroughly, utterly, or absolutely, used to emphasize something negative or extreme
examples: His behavior was downright rude to the guests
The weather has been downright miserable all week

definitions: situated on or relating to a lower floor of a building
examples: The downstairs bathroom needs renovation
We heard noises from the downstairs neighbors

definitions: situated or moving in the direction in which a stream or river flows
examples: The downstream communities were warned about flooding
We found the canoe two miles downstream

definitions: oppressed or treated badly by people in power over a long period
examples: The downtrodden workers finally organized a union
She fought for the rights of downtrodden minorities

definitions: moving or extending toward a lower place, level, or position
examples: The downward trend in prices pleased consumers
She made a downward gesture with her hand

definitions: in the direction that the wind is blowing, carried by the wind
examples: We stayed downwind to avoid the smoke
The downwind leg of the race was much faster

definitions: covered with or resembling soft, fine feathers or hair
examples: The baby bird had downy feathers
She loved the downy softness of the blanket

definitions: lacking brightness or interest; drearily dull and colorless
examples: The drab office walls needed bright artwork
Winter made the landscape look drab and lifeless

definitions: continuing for too long and seeming to pass very slowly
examples: The dragging meeting lasted three hours
His dragging footsteps showed his exhaustion

definitions: having had all liquid removed or emptied out
depleted of physical or emotional energy and vitality
examples: The drained pool needed cleaning before refilling
The drained battery wouldn't start the car
She felt completely drained after the long shift
The drained expression on his face showed his fatigue

definitions: causing someone to feel depleted of energy or emotional resources
examples: The draining work schedule affected her health
Caring for twins can be emotionally draining

definitions: covered, wrapped, or hung with cloth or fabric in loose folds
examples: The draped windows gave the room an elegant look
She sat with a shawl draped over her shoulders

definitions: likely to have a strong or far-reaching effect; extreme and sudden
examples: The company took drastic measures to avoid bankruptcy
Such drastic changes require careful planning

definitions: pulled or attracted toward something as if by an invisible force
looking strained from illness, exhaustion, or anxiety
examples: She felt drawn to the mysterious old house
Moths are drawn to bright lights at night
His drawn face showed the stress of recent events
After the surgery, she looked pale and drawn

definitions: regarded with great fear or apprehension; causing extreme anxiety or terror
examples: The dread disease claimed many lives
Monday morning was his dread time of the week
